column1: A Digital Object Identifier (or DOI) is a permanent way to identify an online document. This identification is not related to its current location.A typical use of a DOI is to give a scientific paper or article a unique number that can be used by anyone find the location of the paper. It may also make it possible to find an electronic copy
column3: on the Internet. The DOI system has a DOI resolution system which is used to locate where the document is. When the document is moved
column4: the DOI resolution system is updated with the new location of the document.For example
column5: doi:10.1016/j.iheduc.2008.03.001 links to "Web 2.0 authorship: Issues of Referencing and citation for academic integrity" by Kathleen Gray et al. The work was published in The Internet and Higher Education
